{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Use British English|date=November 2013}} [[File:The Cathedral of St Giles, Edinburgh - geograph.org.uk - 505970.jpg|300px|thumb| Walter Chepman was a patron of The High Kirk of Edinburgh, also known as Saint Giles' Cathedral.]]
'''Walter Chepman''' was a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[merchant]], [[Notary public|notary]] and civil servant active in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries. Chepman served at the Scottish [[Court (royal)|court]] during the reigns of [[James IV of Scotland|James IV]] and [[James V of Scotland|James V]]. In partnership with [[Androw Myllar]] he established [[Chepman and Myllar Press|Scotland's first printing press]] in 1508.<ref name="C and M prints">[http://digital.nls.uk/firstscottishbooks/index.html The Chepman and Myllar Prints at the National Library of Scotland]</ref><ref name="NLS Breviary">[http://digital.nls.uk/74487406 The Aberdeen Breviary at the National Library of Scotland]</ref> Chepman was also a significant patron of [[St Giles' Cathedral|Saint Giles' Kirk]] in [[Edinburgh]].
==Biography== [[File:Memorial to Walter Chepman.jpg|thumb|Memorial to Walter Chepman in [[St Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh|St. Giles' Cathedral]] erected in 1879 by William Chambers LLD.]] Chepman's first appearance in the historical record is in the accounts of the [[Lord High Treasurer of Scotland]] for 1494 in which he is recorded as receiving payment for clerical work at the royal court.<ref name="ALHTS">[https://archive.org/details/accountsoflordhi03scot Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland, vol.3 (1901), see index, p.470]</ref> He would continue to receive such payments for the remainder of his life.
The impression that Chepman was well-educated is supported by the fact that he acted as a notary in and around Edinburgh.<ref name="DNB">{{cite DNB|wstitle=Chepman, Walter|volume=10|pages=186-187|first=Aeneas James George |last=Mackay}}</ref> His service at court also suggests that he was trusted by King James IV. In 1503, to coincide with the King's marriage, James presented Chepman with a suit of clothes of English fabric.<ref name="ALHTS"/>
Walter Chepman traded in imported textiles and timber and regularly supplied goods to the King.<ref name="ALHTS"/> He appears to have been a prosperous man. He owned [[tenement]]s in Edinburgh's Blackfriars Wynd<ref name="DNB"/> and, at the southern end of this wynd where it joined the Southgait, he and Androw Myllar would establish their press.
Chepman was married twice. His first wife was Margaret Kerkettle and, after being widowed, he married Agnes Cockburn.<ref name="DNB"/>
Chepman died at an unknown point after 1528 and was buried in the chapel he had established at the Kirk of Saint Giles in Edinburgh, now known as the Chepman Aisle.<ref name="DNB"/>
==The Southgait Press== [[File:Goldyn Targe.gif|upright|thumb|Walter Chepman's device in his print of The Goldyn Targe.]] In September 1507 King James IV authorised Walter Chepman and Androw Myllar to establish a printing press and awarded the two partners a monopoly in printed books within Scotland.<ref name="Privy Seal">The Register Of the Privy Seal of Scotland, 15 September 1507. Scottish National Archives.</ref> Androw Myllar was also a burgess of Edinburgh.<ref name="Privy Seal"/> He was a bookseller who had previously published books, printed in Rouen, intended for sale in England.
Chepman and Myllar's press was functional by the following Spring and was based in the [[Cowgate|Southgait]] of Edinburgh. Its works included a liturgical text known as [[Aberdeen Breviary|The Aberdeen Breviary]]<ref name="NLS Breviary"/> and 'The Chepman and Myllar Prints'<ref name="C and M prints"/> which were a series of pamphlets containing popular literature in [[Scots language|Scots]] and [[English language|English]].
The press did not have a long working life. The latest surviving example of its work is an edition of the Aberdeen Breviary dating to 1510.<ref name="Dawson">Jane E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-formed'', The New Edinburgh History of Scotland, Volume 6. Edinburgh University Press, 2007, p.81.</ref>
==Religious Patronage==
Walter Chepman paid for the foundation of two chapels at the Kirk of Saint Giles in Edinburgh.<ref name="DNB"/>
The first chapel, founded in 1513 and abutting to the south of the church, offered [[Office of the Dead|masses for the souls]] of Chepman, his first wife and of the King and [[Margaret Tudor|Queen]]. The equivalent part of the modern church is now known as 'The Chepman Aisle'. It contains the seventeenth century tomb of [[James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose|The Marquess of Montrose]] and a memorial plaque in honour of Walter Chepman donated by the nineteenth century publisher [[William Chambers (publisher)|William Chambers]].<ref name="DNB"/>
In 1528 Chepman established a mortuary chapel, now lost, in the cemetery of Saint Giles' Kirk. It was dedicated to the performance of masses in honour of Chepman, both his wives, King James V, King James IV and all the Scots who had died at [[Battle of Flodden|Flodden]].<ref name="DNB"/>
